awd_titl_txt: REU Site Mystic Aquarium: Collaborative Research: Investigating the Consequences of Global Change on Marine Animals and their Ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Mystic Aquarium (MA) located in Mystic, CT, and the University of Connecticut (U Conn) in Groton, CT, will support the training of 8 students annually for 10 weeks during the summers of 2017- 2019. This award is supported by the Division of Biological Infrastructure in the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Division of Oceanic Sciences in the Directorate for Geosciences. Research is conducted at UConn's Avery Point campus which hosts MA's laboratories and UConn's Department of Marine Sciences. Research is focused on how global change, such as climate change and ocean acidification, affects marine organisms and their ecosystems. Students will be mentored by MA and UConn scientists specializing in aquatic animal physiology, behavior, and ecological processes. Projects span multiple trophic levels of the marine ecosystem, with all students working together to address the overarching question.  Field trips to MA will be a major component, including educational tours, animal and ecosystem exhibit observations, job shadowing, ethics/responsible conduct of research, and science communication. Students will present their findings at MA to scientific and public audiences.  A stipend, housing, meal and travel allowances will be provided.  Students may apply on-line and will be selected based on a personal statement of their interest in marine sciences, academic record, letters of recommendation, and brief explanation of desired research mentors.  Communication with prospective project mentors in advance is encouraged.  

It is anticipated that at least 24 students will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences.  

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://www.mysticaquarium.org/reu or by contacting the PI (Dr. Tracy Romano at tromano@mysticaquarium.org) or Co-PI (Dr. Michael Finiguerra at michael.finiguerra@uconn.edu).

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
REU Site Mystic Aquarium:  Collaborative Research:  Investigating the Consequences of Global Change on Marine Animals and their Ecosystems,  was a success during all three years of NSF support. Students were immersed in world-class innovative marine science research, took full advantage of the resources of Mystic Aquarium and the University of Connecticut, and most presented their work at international conferences and were co-authors on scientific manuscripts.  

The Mystic Aquarium-University of Connecticut REU engaged students, including those from underrepresented groups in authentic marine science research related to the impact of global change on marine ecosystems. Each student mentor pair focused on a different trophic level of the food web. Special interactive sessions at the Aquarium's exhibits demonstrated ecosystems and reinforced connections of the food web as well as potential ecosystem threats. The cohort discussed their individual research projects as a group, reinforcing the integration of scientific disciplines and connections between projects and marine ecosystems.

The REU culminated in students presenting their research to a scientific audience via a 15-minute power point presentation during a scientific symposium at the University of Connecticut and presenting their research to the public on the main floor of the Aquarium via more informal poster presentations. In addition, students continuously developed their communication of science through social media, traditional media, videotaped interviews that are posted on the Mystic Aquarium REU website and exchange of elevator speeches or short overviews and significance of their projects. Professional development sessions and job shadows at the Aquarium provided students with exposure to career opportunities, how to apply to graduate school, ethics in science, scientific writing, and other relevant skills and topics.

The REU met and/or exceeded all its targeted goals with 50% of the participants being from underrepresented groups and from institutions in which research and STEM opportunities are limited. Over the course of launching the first 3 years of the REU, a total of 24 students were served, 18 females and 6 males. Thirteen of the 24 student participants (54%) were from underrepresented groups (7 Hispanic; 3 African American; 2 Native American; 1 Alaska Native). Eight students were first generation college students and eleven students attended either 4 year or 2- year colleges in which research and STEM opportunities are limited. To date, 12 out of 24 students have gone on to graduate school and 7 others are currently in STEM related jobs.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/28/2022
Modified by: Tracy A Romano
